reviewText: A movie only for gamers who have seen Gamer and Gamerz. Whoooowah! It's hilarious and off beat and just what the sub genre should be. Also check out Pirates of the Great Salt Lake, some feel and pretty damn funny.

reviewText: A solid effort from Utah Indie filmmakers.  In the spirit of Bottle Rocket, Napoleon Dynamite, and dreamers everywhere.  Far from a re-creation of the influences it displays, the movie stands on its own with honest, & honestly motivated characters.  A couple of pacing issues shouldn't detract anyone from the download/DVD or preferred method of film enjoyment.A real standout amongst "focus group developed" fare & other summer offerings.
summary: In the spirit of Peter Jackson and Jon Heder.....
Title: N/A

reviewText: It's always nice to see a new independent movie, especially one that doesn't take itself seriously.This movie kept my interest enough to finish it, although the plot seemed a little aimless near the beginning. But once the main character found his cause the movie was off and running.I am not into the the LARP thing so a lot of my laughs were directed at the characters and what they were doing. I'm not sure if I was supposed to be laughing at them or along with them. But I've played enough D&D;, Warcraft, etc. to get at least some of the inside jokes. I love the "Warlocks of the Beach."The setting feels like a place not too far away from the town of Napoleon Dynamite. It's got that same "kinder and gentler" but also goofy feel.For me, the beautiful Jaclyn Hales stole the show with her character Marsha, even though she is a supporting character.The best way to watch this movie is just go along with the ride.[update]Bumping my rating up to 5 stars after the second viewing. This movie really is still enjoyable the second time around - a rare thing for me with movies. You see stuff you missed the first time.
Title: N/A

reviewText: My choice of title for this review is based on the fact that this story is very true to life: LARPers (live action role players) do act that way and D&Ders; (Dungeons & Dragons players) get into LARPing in very like-ways that this film dramatizes. Mood altering prescription drugs are commonplace among those who feel that they are "born in the wrong universe": Voss's girlfriend is clearly, and self-admittedly, emotionally dependent on her "meds". So the immediate background to Unicorn City's "population" is actually a window on that kind of society and subculture.Production values for a "B" movie are first rate. Direction and screen play are very good. Acting all around is first rate too. I loved many of the lines and scenes and there are quite a few quotable ones that could very well become stock, household toss-around quality, on a par with Monty Python's "Holy Grail".My favorite character is the "centaur". What a getup! :D The chicks are rather too-good looking for the average "geek chick", but hey, Voss's group of friends are above average as interesting characters, so they deserve interesting, good-looking chicks. Geek chicks have been improving in "quality" lately, so the ones in Unicorn City are actually more typical of today's Geek Chicks, than what I am accustomed to from my youth.If you want to enjoy a few genuine laughs, and want to be "educated" into the mentality of LARPers in your midst, then Unicorn City is likely to provide satisfaction.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Unicorn City" is what happens when tabletop role-players throw off the shackles of the gaming table and take it to the outside world.  Gamers can commiserate, be it tiring of a tyrannical game master (Jon Gries), annoyed by the rowdy public spaces of game stores, or just wanting more excitement in props -- "Unicorn City" fulfills the fantasy that every gamer probably had at some point: What if I could make it all real?  Or at least, as close to real as possible without making it hurt?The answer is Live Action Role-Playing, but like so many nascent game designers, it doesn't occur to Voss (Devin McGinn) that such a thing might already exist.  Nowadays we have True Dungeon: It's Dungeons & Dragons for gamers that want the feel of a true dungeon environment without having to immerse themselves in a role.  In "Unicorn City," Voss finally realizes that even his extensive gaming experience is not sufficient to net him the ultimate gaming job in Washington State: Working for Wizards of the Coast -- excuse me, "Warlocks of the Beach" in this film.  How will he prove that he can be a leader when all his leadership has only taken place in a fantasy world?By making the fantasy world real of course! Does it bear mentioning that Voss plays a bard?  Are you surprised?And so Voss conducts a secret power struggle for the soul of his group: his live-in roommate, the gamer guy with the clingy girlfriend who tags along, the tough dude who'll play anything if he can kick butt, and the foreign guy who doesn't always understand what's going on.  These are stereotypes, but they are nuanced stereotypes that go beyond the dork who knows everything about geekdom (I'm looking at you, Big Bang Theory). It's a welcome change that's only possible because the writers are gamers.There's also a delightfully nerdy gamer chick who makes her own dresses.  Marsha (Jaclyn Hales) is adorable in a pretty-ugly girl sort of way, but Voss can't see it.  The writers gave her another quirk too -- under stress, she has to take her medication -- that makes her vulnerable and believable.  She may be cute, but she belongs in this geeky world of outsiders.And so our fearless heroes decide to embark on a fantasy world of their own creation titled "Unicorn City," in which people dress up like monsters and attack each other in a field.  "Unicorn City" takes particular glee in scrubbing the shine off LARPing by demonstrating that it's essentially camping with swords. Eventually, the aforementioned tyrannical GM (Shadowhawk) discovers what the group is up to and returns to reclaim the soul, if not the heart, of the group."Unicorn City's" climax reaches cult-like proportions that eventually involves the police, but somehow manages to sweetly and hilariously tie everything up in a way that's satisfying.  This is a love note to any tabletop gamer who has had the urge to run away screaming from the table, holy avenger in hand.

reviewText: My husband and I have been gaming for years.  We watched this movie last night.  I thought it was really well done.  Our favorite character was Rhubarb with his cooler.  Really enjoyed it and have recommended that my friends who game and also like to do fan films watch it.  It was clean, simply done without a ton of bells and whistles.  REFRESHING change from all the CGI movies out there.Thank you to the producers of Unicorn City and its cast.  This is a movie we will be sharing with our kids and friends.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was sucked into Unicorn City.  This was a film done by gamers for gamers.The stereotypes were over-the-top, but not without some basis in gamer reality.The story revolves around a slacker gamer in a really bad campaign that wants to move out of his brother's apartment (where the protagonist literally sleeps in the coat closet) and go to work for "warlocks of the beach" (WotB).  (The film is full of wonderful nods to gaming reality like that one.)He is being pursued by a lovely lady, and our hero is totally oblivious.He gets the idea that his group could create a live-in LARP as a way of demonstrating his managerial acumen to the WotB.His nemesis, the DM from the horrible campaign, finds out and lures away the Unicorn City followers.I won't give the end away, but I saw no way out of the dilemma presented until the last ten minutes of the film.The movie is full of witty and fun asides, e.g., the WotB interviewer says, "I've never seen a calligraphied resume before!"  Most gamers could imagine someone actually doing that.All in all, this is a great film that is fun for the whole family.Well done!In service,Rich

reviewText: I don't do Role Playing, or LARPing, but I know people who do... which makes this movie that much funnier.It's made by a small production company, the production value is low-ish, but it is a well-put together story, filmed well, and jam packed with silly nerd humor.It's the perfect gift to get the nerd who's impossible to shop for.I bought 3 of these to give away as birthday presents this spring.
